content: The "Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress acknowledges that bullying and harassment in schools can have serious physical and psychological effects on victims, leading to academic issues such as high dropout rates and absenteeism. These behaviors hinder students' ability to learn and participate in educational opportunities. Bullying and harassment in schools can include hitting, name-calling, intimidation, and sending offensive messages through various electronic means. Schools with anti-bullying policies see increased reporting and teacher intervention, reducing the frequency of incidents. Students are targeted based on race, color, national origin, sex, disability status, sexual orientation, gender identity, or religion. Creating a positive and safe school climate, along with evidence-based discipline policies like PBIS and restorative practices, can reduce suspensions and expulsions, preventing students from being pushed out to the juvenile justice system. 85% of Americans support a Federal law to prevent bullying, and there is a call for leadership to address the national crisis of bullying and harassment. The purpose of the Safe Schools Improvement Act is to address bullying and harassment in public elementary and secondary schools through the implementation of anti-bullying policies. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires states receiving grants to ensure that all local educational agencies establish policies to prevent and prohibit bullying, including cyberbullying, that creates a hostile or abusive educational environment. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates policies at public schools to prevent bullying and harassment based on various characteristics like race, gender, disability, and religion. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires schools to prevent bullying and harassment based on characteristics like race, gender, disability, religion, sexual orientation, and other defining traits as defined by the educational agency. Schools must provide annual notice of prohibited conduct and grievance procedures for complaints. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates schools to prevent bullying and harassment based on various characteristics. Schools must provide grievance procedures for complaints and collect annual data on incidents of prohibited conduct. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires schools to collect and publicly report accurate data on prohibited conduct at the school and district levels. It also emphasizes positive and preventative approaches to school discipline to minimize student removal from instruction and ensure fair treatment for all students. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates State reports on local educational agencies' data and plans to address prohibited conduct. The Secretary will conduct a biennial evaluation of programs to combat bullying in schools, including data collection on prohibited conduct. A report will be submitted to the President and Congress every two years. The Secretary will submit a biennial report to the President and Congress on the findings of the evaluation of programs to combat bullying in schools, including collected data. "SEC. 4705. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS." The section states that federal and state nondiscrimination laws remain valid and unaffected by the regulations outlined in this part. This includes laws such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Education Amendments of 1972, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The obligations imposed by this part are additional to those imposed by the mentioned laws. The regulations outlined in this part do not affect federal and state nondiscrimination laws, including the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Education Amendments of 1972, Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The part does not change legal standards or rights under other laws protecting freedom of speech or expression. The text chunk discusses Section 4706, which clarifies that states can enact laws to prevent bullying or harassment of students as long as they are not inconsistent with the regulations outlined in the Safe Schools Improvement part. This section is added to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
